FedDisco: Federated Learning with Discrepancy-Aware Collaboration

Rui Ye â€ƒâ€ƒ Mingkai Xu â€ƒâ€ƒ Jianyu Wang â€ƒâ€ƒ Chenxin Xu â€ƒâ€ƒ Siheng Chen â€ƒâ€ƒ Yanfeng Wang
Abstract

This work considers the category distribution heterogeneity in federated learning. This issue is due to biased labeling preferences at multiple clients and is a typical setting of data heterogeneity. To alleviate this issue, most previous works consider either regularizing local models or fine-tuning the global model, while they ignore the adjustment of aggregation weights and simply assign weights based on the dataset size. However, based on our empirical observations and theoretical analysis, we find that the dataset size is not optimal and the discrepancy between local and global category distributions could be a beneficial and complementary indicator for determining aggregation weights. We thus propose a novel aggregation method, Federated Learning with Discrepancy-aware Collaboration (FedDisco), whose aggregation weights not only involve both the dataset size and the discrepancy value, but also contribute to a tighter theoretical upper bound of the optimization error. FedDisco also promotes privacy-preservation, communication and computation efficiency, as well as modularity. Extensive experiments show that our FedDisco outperforms several state-of-the-art methods and can be easily incorporated with many existing methods to further enhance the performance. Our code will be available at https://github.com/MediaBrain-SJTU/FedDisco.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging field that offers a privacy-preserving collaborative machine learning paradigmÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2019). Its main idea is to enable multiple clients to collaboratively train a shared global model by sharing information about model parameters. FL algorithms have been widely applied to many real-world scenarios, such as usersâ€™ next-word predictionÂ (Hard etÂ al., 2018), recommendation systemsÂ (Ding etÂ al., 2022), and smart healthcareÂ (Kaissis etÂ al., 2020).

In spite of the promising trend, there are still multiple key challenges that impede the further development of FL, including data heterogeneity, communication cost and privacy concernsÂ (Kairouz etÂ al., 2019). In this work, we focus on one critical issue in data heterogeneity:Â category distribution heterogeneity; that is, clients have drastically different category distributions. For example, some clients have many samples in category 1 but very few in category 2; while other clients are opposite. This setting is common in practice, since clients collect local data privately and usually tend to have biased labeling preferences. Due to this heterogeneity, different local models are optimized towards different local objectives, causing divergent optimization directions. It is thus difficult to aggregate these divergent local models to obtain a robust global model. This unpleasant phenomenon has been theoretically and empirically verified inÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2018; Li etÂ al., 2019; Wang etÂ al., 2021).

To mitigate the negative impact of category distribution heterogeneity, there are mainly two approaches: i) local model adjustment at the client side and ii) global model adjustment at the server side. Most previous works consider the first approach. For example, FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a) and FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2020) introduce regularization terms; and MOONÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021) aligns intermediate outputs of local and global models to reduce the variance among optimized local models. Along the line of the second approach, FedDF and FedFTGÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2022) introduce an additional fine-tuning step to refine the global model. Despite all these diverse efforts, few works consider optimizing the aggregation weight at the server side111FedNovaÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020b) targets system heterogeneity.. In fact, most previous works simply aggregate the local models according to the dataset size at each local client. However, the dataset size does not reflect any categorical information and thus cannot provide sufficient information of a local client. It is still unclear whether the dataset size based aggregation is the best aggregation strategy.

In this paper, we first answer the above open question by empirically showing that, in many cases, aggregating local models based on the local dataset size is consistently far from optimal; meanwhile, incorporating the discrepancy between local and global category distributions into the aggregation weights could be beneficial. Intuitively, a lower discrepancy value reflects that the private data at a local client has a more similar category distribution with the hypothetically aggregated global data, and the corresponding client should contribute more to the global model than those with higher discrepancy values. To understand the effect of category distribution heterogeneity, we next provide a theoretical analysis for federated averaging with arbitrary aggregation weights, dataset sizes and local discrepancy levels. By minimizing the reformulated upper bound of the optimization error, we obtain an optimized aggregation weights for clients, which depend on not only the local dataset sizes but also the local discrepancy levels.

Inspired by the above empirical and theoretical observations, we propose a novel model aggregation method, federated learning with discrepancy-aware collaboration (FedDisco), to alleviate the category distribution heterogeneity issue. This new method leverages each clientâ€™s dataset size and discrepancy in determining aggregation weight by assigning larger aggregation weights to those clients with larger dataset sizes and smaller discrepancy values. As a novel model aggregation scheme, FedDisco is still privacy-preserving and can be easily incorporated with many FL methods, such as FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a) and MOONÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021). Compared to the vanilla aggregation based on local dataset size, FedDisco nearly introduces no additional computation and communication costs.

To validate the effectiveness of our proposed FedDisco, we conduct extensive experiments under diverse scenarios, such as various heterogeneous settings, globally balanced and imbalanced distributions, full and partial client participation, and across four datasets. We observe that FedDisco can significantly and consistently improve the performance over existing FL algorithms.

The main contributions of this paper is listed as follows:

  1. 1.

    We empirically show that the dataset size is not optimal to determine aggregation weights in FL and the discrepancy between local and global category distributions could be a beneficial complementary indicator;

  2. 2.

    We theoretically show that aggregation weight correlated with both dataset size and discrepancy could contribute to a tighter error bound;

  3. 3.

    We propose a novel aggregation method, called FedDisco (federated learning with discrepancy-aware collaboration), whose aggregation weight follows from the optimization of the theoretical error bound;

  4. 4.

    Extensive experiments show that FedDisco achieves state-of-the-art performances under diverse scenarios.

As mentioned in introduction, the category distribution heterogeneity issue could cause different local objectives in local training. To address this, many previous works focus on adjustment on training ğ°k(t,Ï„)superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğœ\mathbf{w}_{k}^{(t,\tau)}, while neglects the adjustment of aggregation weight pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}. In fact, most previous works conduct model aggregation simply based on the local dataset relative size; that is, pk=nksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜p_{k}=n_{k}. However, we notice that dataset-size-based weighted aggregation could be not optimal in empirical investigation, which motivate us to search for a better aggregation strategy. The empirical observations are delivered in the next section.

3 Empirical Observations

This section presents a series of empirical observations, which motivate us to consider a new form of aggregation weight and propose our method. In the experiments, we divide the CIFAR-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) dataset into 101010 clients, whose local category distributions are heterogeneous and follow commonly used Dirichlet distributionÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020a); see FigureÂ 2 (a). Based on this common setting, we conduct the following experiments.

To explore the relationship between the aggregation weight and the performance of aggregated global model, we conduct three independent trials, where each trial considers federated training of two clients with similar dataset sizes. In each trial, each client trains a model (denoted as A and B) for 101010 epochs and we aggregate these two models following: ğ°agg=(1âˆ’r)â€‹ğ°A+râ€‹ğ°Bsubscriptğ°agg1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ°Ağ‘Ÿsubscriptğ°B\mathbf{w}_{\rm agg}=(1-r)\mathbf{w}_{\rm A}+r\mathbf{w}_{\rm B}. FigureÂ 2 (b) shows three curves, which are the testing results of the aggregated model ğ°aggsubscriptğ°agg\mathbf{w}_{\rm agg} as a function of aggregation weight rğ‘Ÿr in three trials, respectively. Note that r=0ğ‘Ÿ0r=0 reflects Model A, r=1ğ‘Ÿ1r=1 reflects Model B, and r=0.5ğ‘Ÿ0.5r=0.5 represents dataset-size-based weighted aggregation. We observe that i) it is not optimal to determine aggregation weights purely based on local dataset size. The performances at r=0.5ğ‘Ÿ0.5r=0.5 could be far from the optimal performances (stars in the plot); and ii) best performance is achieved when assigning a relatively larger weight rğ‘Ÿr to a better-performed local model. In these trials, Model B outperforms Model A, and the best performance is achieved when Model B has a larger weight (rğ‘Ÿr is around 0.7âˆ¼0.9similar-to0.70.90.7\sim 0.9). Similar phenomena can be seen in ensemble learningÂ (JimÃ©nez, 1998; Shen & Kong, 2004), which assigns larger weight to better model in ensemble.

To search for indicators that can reflect local modelâ€™s performance and eventually appropriate aggregation weight, we explore the effects of two informative properties of client in category heterogeneity scenario: dataset size and discrepancy between local and global category distribution. Here we use â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} distance to measure the discrepancy. We plot all 101010 clients in FigureÂ 2 (c) & (d), where y-axis denote the local modelâ€™s testing accuracy and x-axis in (c) and (d) denotes clientâ€™s dataset relative size and discrepancy level, respectively. We highlight four clients in a circle, which have similar dataset sizes. Comparing these two plots, we clearly see that the discrepancy level is a better indicator to reflect the local modelâ€™s performance than the dataset size. In plot (c), we see that these clients have similar dataset sizes but largely different performances; while in plot (d), the discrepancy level clearly reflects the performance difference among these four clients, that is, the client with a smaller discrepancy performs better.

Based on these observations, we hypothesize that, in FL, when a client has a smaller discrepancy value, it might have a better-performed model and thus need a larger weight in aggregation. Motivated by this, we propose to leverage discrepancy in determining the aggregation weight of each client, which is theoretically analyzed in the following.

4 Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we firstly obtain a convergence error bound for FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), which highlights the effect of aggregation weight pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}, dataset size nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} and discrepancy level dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k}. Then, a concise analytical expression of the optimized aggregation weight is derived by minimizing the error bound, which indicates that aggregation weight should depend on both dataset size and local discrepancy level.

Optimization error upper bound.

Our analysis is based on the following four standard assumptions in FL.

For each client, the stochastic gradient is unbiased: ğ”¼Î¾â€‹[gkâ€‹(ğ°|Î¾)]=âˆ‡Fkâ€‹(ğ°)subscriptğ”¼ğœ‰delimited-[]subscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜conditionalğ°ğœ‰âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ°\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[g_{k}(\mathbf{w}|\xi)]=\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}), and has bounded variance: ğ”¼Î¾[||gk(ğ°|Î¾)âˆ’âˆ‡Fk(ğ°)||2]â‰¤Ïƒ2\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[||g_{k}(\mathbf{w}|\xi)-\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w})||^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}.

All assumptions are commonly used in federated learning literature (Wang etÂ al., 2020b; Li etÂ al., 2020a, 2019; Reddi etÂ al., 2021). As no previous literature has considered discrepancy in their theory, a new assumption is required to include discrepancy. However, rather than introducing an additional assumption, we slightly adjust standard dissimilarity assumptionÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020b) and applyÂ 4.4 to include the discrepancy level, this modification correlates the gradient dissimilarity and distribution discrepancy, and enables us to explore the relationships among aggregation weight pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}, dataset relative size nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} and discrepancy dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k}.

Generally, a tighter bound corresponds to a better optimization result. Thus, we explore the effects of pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} on upper bound. InÂ TheoremÂ 4.5, there are four parts related to pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}. First, we see that larger difference between pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} and nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} contributes to larger WDsubscriptğ‘Šğ·W_{D} and thus smaller denominator in T0subscriptğ‘‡0T_{0} and larger value in T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2}, which tends to loose the bound. As for T5subscriptğ‘‡5T_{5}, by setting pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} negatively correlated to dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k}, when clients have different level of discrepancy, i.e. different dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k}, T5subscriptğ‘‡5T_{5} will be further reduced, which tends to tight the bound.

Therefore, there could be an optimal set of {pk|kâˆˆ[K]}conditional-setsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\{p_{k}|k\in[K]\} that contributes to the tightest bound, where an optimal pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} should be correlated to both nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} and dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k}. This theoretically show that dataset size could be not the optimal indicator and that discrepancy level can be a reasonable complementary indicator for determining aggregation weight.

Upper bound minimization.

In the following, we derive the analytical expression of aggregation weight (pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}) by minimizing the upper bound inÂ TheoremÂ 4.5. To minimize this upper bound, directly solving the minimization results in a complicated expression, which involves too many unknown hyper-parameters in practice. 5 FL with Discrepancy-Aware Collaboration

Motivated by these empirical and theoretical observations, we propose federated learning with discrepancy-aware collaboration (FedDisco).

5.1 Framework

FedDisco involves four key steps: localÂ model training, local discrepancy computation, discrepancy-aware aggregation weight determination and global model aggregation. Steps 1 and 4 follows from the standard federated learning; meanwhile, Steps 2 and 3 integrates the discrepancy between local and global category distributions into aggregation weights. The overview is shown on the right of FigureÂ 3. We also provide an algorithm flow inÂ AlgorithmÂ 1.

LocalÂ modelÂ training. Each client kğ‘˜k performs Ï„ğœ\tau steps of local training based on dataset â„¬ksubscriptâ„¬ğ‘˜\mathcal{B}_{k} and initial model ğ°(t,0)superscriptğ°ğ‘¡0\mathbf{w}^{(t,0)} to obtain the trained model, denoted as ğ°k(t,Ï„)=Lâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Tâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹(â„¬k,ğ°(t,0)).superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğœğ¿ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptâ„¬ğ‘˜superscriptğ°ğ‘¡0\mathbf{w}_{k}^{(t,\tau)}=LocalTrain(\mathcal{B}_{k},\mathbf{w}^{(t,0)}).

Local discrepancy computation. Each client needs to compute the discrepancy between its local category distribution and the hypothetically aggregated global category distribution. Here we consider that the global category distribution is uniform, since it naturally promotes the fairness across all categories and the generalization capability of the global model. Moreover, each local client can compute its discrepancy without additional data sharing, preventing information leakage of category distribution. Concretely, ğƒksubscriptğƒğ‘˜\mathbf{D}_{k} and ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T} denote local and global category distribution. Thus, we set all elements ğ“c=1/Csubscriptğ“ğ‘1ğ¶\mathbf{T}_{c}={1}/{C} to treat all categories equally. Given the global distribution ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T}, each client kğ‘˜k can calculate its local discrepancy level dkâˆˆâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜â„d_{k}\in\mathbb{R} by evaluating the difference between these two distributions: dk=eâ€‹(ğƒk,ğ“),subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜ğ‘’subscriptğƒğ‘˜ğ“d_{k}=e(\mathbf{D}_{k},\mathbf{T}), where eâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘’â‹…e(\cdot) is a pre-defined metric function (e.g. L2 difference or KL-Divergence). Applying L2 difference corresponds to dk=âˆ‘c=1C(ğƒk,câˆ’ğ“c)2subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ¶superscriptsubscriptğƒğ‘˜ğ‘subscriptğ“ğ‘2d_{k}=\sqrt{\sum_{c=1}^{C}(\mathbf{D}_{k,c}-\mathbf{T}_{c})^{2}}. Finally, the server collects clientsâ€™ discrepancy levels, see the left of FigureÂ 3. Note that though we are more interested in uniform target distribution for the sake of category-level fairness, our method is also applicable to scenarios where target distribution is imbalanced; see experiments inÂ TableÂ 5.

Discrepancy-awareÂ aggregationÂ weightÂ determination. Motivated by the previous empirical and theoretical observations, we propose to determine more distinguishing aggregation weights for each client kğ‘˜k by leveraging dataset relative size nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} and local discrepancy level dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k} (derived fromÂ (2)):

pk=ReLUâ€‹(nkâˆ’aâ‹…dk+b)âˆ‘m=1KReLUâ€‹(nmâˆ’aâ‹…dm+b),subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ReLUsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜â‹…ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ¾ReLUsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘šâ‹…ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘šğ‘p_{k}=\frac{{\rm ReLU}(n_{k}-a\cdot d_{k}+b)}{\sum_{m=1}^{K}{\rm ReLU}(n_{m}-a\cdot d_{m}+b)}, (3)

where ReLU(â‹…)â‹…(\cdot) is the relu function to take care of negative valuesÂ (Fukushima, 1975), ağ‘a is a hyper-parameter to balance nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} and dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k}, bğ‘b is another hyper-parameter to adjust the weight. This Disco aggregation can determine more distinguishing aggregation weights for clients by assigning larger weight for clients with larger dataset sizes and smaller local discrepancy levels.

Global model aggregation. The server conducts model aggregation based on the above discrepancy-aware aggregation weights. The global model is ğ°(t+1)=âˆ‘k=1Kpkâ€‹ğ°k(t),superscriptğ°ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}^{(t+1)}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}\mathbf{w}_{k}^{(t)}, where ğ°k(t)superscriptsubscriptğ°ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}_{k}^{(t)} is the kğ‘˜kth local model.

5.2 Discussions

Privacy. Our proposed FedDisco does not leak clientâ€™s exact distribution (FigureÂ 3) since the discrepancy is calculated at the client side. The server collects discrepancy level of clients, from which the exact category distribution can not be inversely inferred. This indicates that this process is more privacy-preserving compared with several existing works, such as FedFTG and CCVRÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022; Luo etÂ al., 2021), which transmitting exact category distribution.

Communication & computation efficiency. Discrepancy communication is only required at the first communication round. Besides, the discrepancy is only a numerical value, which is negligible compared with the model communication. The discrepancy calculation is only a simple operation between two vectors, which is negligible compared with model training. Moreover, FedDisco requires much less computation overhead and no computation burden to the server; while previous methods, such as FedDFÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2020) and FedFTGÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022), require additional model fine-tuning by simultaneously running Kğ¾K local models at the server side for every communication round.

Modularity. The modularity of FedDisco indicates its broad range of application. Typically, federated learning involves four steps: (1) global model downloading, (2) local updating, (3) local model uploading and (4) model aggregation. Our FedDisco focuses on step 4, which suggests that it can be easily combined with existing works conducting correction in step 2 and compression in step 1 and 3. Beyond this, it could also be incorporated with methods in step 4 by adjusting aggregation weight to be negatively correlated with discrepancy, such as conducting Disco re-weighting before normalization in FedNovaÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020b).

6 Related Works

Federated learning (FL) has been an emerging topicÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Hao etÂ al., 2020). However, data distribution heterogeneity may significantly degrades FLâ€™s performanceÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2018; Kairouz etÂ al., 2019; Li etÂ al., 2019). Works that focus on this can be mainly divided into two directions: local and global model adjustment.

6.1 Local Model Adjustment

Methods in this direction conduct the adjustment on local model training at the client side, aiming at producing local models with smaller differenceÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020). FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a) regularizes the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}-distance between local and global model. FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2020) proposes a dynamic regularizer to align the local and global solutions. SCAFFOLDÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020) and FedDCÂ (Gao etÂ al., 2022) introduce control variates to correct each clientâ€™s gradient but require double communication cost. MOONÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021) aligns the features of local and global model; FedFMÂ (Ye etÂ al., 2022) aligns category-wise feature space across clients, contributing to more consistent feature spaces.

All of these methods simply assign aggregation weight based on local dataset size, which is not sufficient to distinguish each clientâ€™s contribution. While our proposed FedDisco leverages both dataset size and discrepancy between local and global category distributions to determine more distinguishing aggregation weights, which has strong ability of plug-and-play that can be easily incorporated with these methods to further enhance the overall performance.

6.2 Global Model Adjustment

Methods in this direction conducts the adjustment on global model at the server side, aiming at produce a global model with better performanceÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2020; Reddi etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2023; Zhang etÂ al., 2023; Fan etÂ al., 2022). FedNovaÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020b) conducts re-weighting to target system heterogeneity while we conduct re-weighting based on local discrepancy level to target data heterogeneity. CCVRÂ (Luo etÂ al., 2021) conducts post-calibration, FedAvgMÂ (Hsu etÂ al., 2019) and FedOPTÂ (Reddi etÂ al., 2021) introduce global model momentum to stabilize FL training; while these methods are orthogonal to FedDisco and can be easily combined. FedDFÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2020) and FedFTGÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022) introduce an additional fine-tuning step to refine the global model; FedGenÂ (Zhu etÂ al., 2021) learns a feature generator for assisting local training. However, these methods require great computation capability of the server with much more computation cost (e.g. FedFTGÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022) requires twice computation cost compared with FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017)). As a contrast, our FedDisco brings no computation burden to the server and works with negligible computation overhead.

7 Experiments

We show key experimental setups and results in this section. More details and results are inÂ AppendixÂ B.

7.1 Experimental Setup

Datasets. We consider five image classification datasets to cover medical, natural and artificial scenarios, including HAM10000Â (Tschandl etÂ al., 2018), CIFAR-10 & CIFAR-100Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009), CINIC-10Â (Darlow etÂ al., 2018) and Fashion-MNISTÂ (Xiao etÂ al., 2017); and AG NewsÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2015), a text classification dataset.

Federated scenarios. We consider two data distribution heterogeneous settings, termed NIID-1 and NIID-2. NIID-1 follows Dirichlet distributionÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020a; Li etÂ al., 2021) Dâ€‹iâ€‹rÎ²ğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ›½Dir_{\beta}, where Î²ğ›½\beta (default 0.50.50.5) is an argument correlated with heterogeneity level. We consider 101010 clients for NIID-1. NIID-2 is a more heterogeneous setting consists of 555 biased clients (each has data from C/5ğ¶5{C}/{5} categoriesÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Li etÂ al., 2020a)) and 111 unbiased client (has all Cğ¶C categories), where Cğ¶C is the total category number.

Implementation details. The number of local epochs and batch size are 101010 and 646464, respectively. We run federated learning for 100100100 rounds. We use ResNet18Â (He etÂ al., 2016) for HAM10000, a simple CNN network for other image datasets and TextCNNÂ (Zhang & Wallace, 2015) for AG News. We use SGD optimizer with a 0.010.010.01 learning rate. We evaluate the accuracy on the global testing set. We use KL-Divergence to measure the discrepancy.

Baselines. We compare FedDisco with eight representative baselines. Among these, 1) FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) is the pioneering FL method; 2) FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a), SCAFFOLDÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020), FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2020), MOONÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021), and FedDCÂ (Gao etÂ al., 2022) focus on local model adjustment; 3) FedAvgMÂ (Hsu etÂ al., 2019) and FedNovaÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020b) focus on global model adjustment. The tuned hyper-parameters are shown inÂ SectionÂ B.1.5.

7.2 Main Results

On four standard datasets and two types of heterogeneity, we compare FedDisco with state-of-the-art algorithms, show the modularity of FedDisco, and explore FedDiscoâ€™s broader scope of applications.

Performance: state-of-the-art accuracy. We compare the accuracy of several state-of-the-art methods and our proposed FedDisco on multiple heterogeneous settings and datasets in TableÂ 1. Note that HAM10000 is an imbalanced dataset and thus is not applicable for NIID-2. The local training protocol used in FedDisco is FedDyn except SCAFFOLD for Fashion-MNIST. Experiments show that i) our proposed FedDisco consistently outperforms others across different settings, indicating the effectiveness of our proposed method; ii) FedDisco achieves significantly better on NIID-1 setting of HAM10000 (Î²=5ğ›½5\beta=5), which is a more difficult task for its severe heterogeneity and imbalance.

Modularity: improvements over baselines. One key advantage of our proposed FedDisco is its modularity, that is, it can be a plug-and-play module in many existing FL methods to further improve their performance. Following the experiments inÂ TableÂ 1, we report the accuracy of baselines combined with our Disco module and the accuracy difference (in parentheses) compared with baselines without Disco inÂ TableÂ 2 (see CIFAR-100 inÂ TableÂ 11). Experiments show that i) Disco consistently enhances the performance of state-of-the-art methods under different datasets and heterogeneity types; ii) for the most difficult task (i.e., HAM10000), FedDisco brings the largest performance improvement. Specifically, it achieves 19.8%percent19.819.8\% relative accuracy improvement over FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017).

Applicability to partial client participation scenarios. Partial client participation is a common scenario in cross-device FL applications where only a subset of clients are available in a specific FL round. To verify that our proposed FedDisco is applicable to this scenario, we sample 101010 out of 606060 clients for each round under NIID-2 on CIFAR-10, which consists of 505050 biased clients and 101010 unbiased clients. We report the averaged accuracy of last 101010 rounds and the number of rounds to reach target accuracy (55%percent5555\%) inÂ TableÂ 3. We see that Disco module significantly i) brings performance gain to baselines (up to 7.32%percent7.327.32\%); ii) reduces the communication cost to reach a target accuracy (up to 65.52%percent65.5265.52\%). These results indicate that FedDisco not only improves the accuracy but also speeds up the training process under this scenario.

Applicability to text-modality scenarios. To verify that our proposed FedDisco can also be applied to text-modality, we explore on a text classification dataset, AG NewsÂ (Tschandl etÂ al., 2018) under full and partial participation scenarios. Results inÂ TableÂ 4 show that Disco still consistently improves the baselines on text modality and brings significant performance gain under partial client participation scenario.

Applicability to globally imbalanced scenarios. Here, we verify that FedDisco is also capable of globally imbalanced category distribution scenario, that is the hypothetically aggregated global data is imbalanced. We firstly allocate CIFAR-10 to each category cğ‘c following an exponential distributionÂ (Cui etÂ al., 2019): nc=n1â€‹Ïâˆ’câˆ’1Câˆ’1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ‘›1superscriptğœŒğ‘1ğ¶1n_{c}=n_{1}\rho^{-\frac{c-1}{C-1}}, where ÏğœŒ\rho denotes the imbalance ratio and C=10ğ¶10C=10 is the total category number, n1=5000subscriptğ‘›15000n_{1}=5000. The dataset is then distributed to 101010 clients as NIID-1. Note that Ï=1ğœŒ1\rho=1 denotes globally balanced, Ï=20ğœŒ20\rho=20 is the most imbalanced, where category 111 has 500050005000 samples while category 101010 only has 250250250 samples. We consider two scenarios 1) the global category distribution is non-uniform while the distribution of test dataset is uniform; 2) the global category distribution and the distribution of test dataset are similar, and both non-uniform.

1) We conduct experiments on two typical baselines, FedAvg and FedDyn inÂ FigureÂ 5(a). Experiments show that our FedDisco consistently improves the baseline regardless of the globally imbalance level; see more results inÂ SectionÂ B.2.

2) We conduct experiments under two scenarios (Ï=10ğœŒ10\rho=10 and Ï=50ğœŒ50\rho=50) and report the results inÂ TableÂ 5. Experiments show that FedDisco still performs the best when both global and test category distribution are non-uniform; see how to obtain global category distribution in a privacy-preserving way inÂ SectionÂ A.3.

7.3 Numerical Simulation of Reformulation

InÂ SectionÂ 4, we minimize the reformulated the upper bound inÂ TheoremÂ 4.5 for obtaining a concise expression, which benefits the practical utility as the tuning efforts are mitigated. Here, we conduct numerical simulation to examine the optimization process of the original form of upper bound inÂ TheoremÂ 4.5 and the reformulated form inÂ SectionÂ 4. We run 400400400 steps of gradient descent on {pk}subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\{p_{k}\} by minimizing the reformulated form, and record the resulting values of both reformulated and original form inÂ TableÂ 6. Results show that minimizing the reformulated form benefit minimizing the original form, verifying the rationality of such reformulation during derivation.

7.4 Ablation Study

Ease of hyper-parameter tuning. We tune ağ‘a and bğ‘b in Â (3) under four settings to illustrate the ease of hyper-parameter tuning for our proposed FedDisco. For more comprehensive understanding, we consider multiple scenarios, including different baseline methods (FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) and MOONÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021)), heterogeneity types (NIID-1 and NIID-2) and datasets (CIFAR-10 and CINIC-10). We plot the accuracy difference brought by Disco for each group of hyper-parameters in FigureÂ 4. By comparing three pairs: (a)&(b), (b)&(c) and (c)&(d), we see that i) for a wide range (aâˆˆ[0.2,0.7],bâˆˆ[0.05,0.4]formulae-sequenceğ‘0.20.7ğ‘0.050.4a\in[0.2,0.7],b\in[0.05,0.4]), our Disco brings performance improvement for most cases regardless of the baseline method, heterogeneity type and dataset; ii) generally, a=0.4âˆ¼0.6,b=0.1formulae-sequenceğ‘0.4similar-to0.6ğ‘0.1a=0.4\sim 0.6,b=0.1 is a safe choice, which leads to stable and great performance.

Effects of client number, heterogeneity level and local epoch. We tune three key arguments in FL, including client number (Kâˆˆ{10,30,50}ğ¾103050K\in\{10,30,50\}), heterogeneity level (smaller value corresponds to more severe heterogeneity, Î²âˆˆ{0.1,0.3,0.5}ğ›½0.10.30.5\beta\in\{0.1,0.3,0.5\}) and number of local epoch Eâˆˆ{2,10,20}ğ¸21020E\in\{2,10,20\}, and show the accuracy improvement brought by Disco inÂ FigureÂ 5(b), 5(c), and 5(d), respectively. Experiments show that our proposed Disco consistently brings performance improvement across different FL arguments.

Effects of different discrepancy metrics. Unless specified, we use the KL-Divergence throughout the paper. Though, TableÂ 7 compares four discrepancy metrics under NIID-1 on CIFAR-10, including L1&L2 norm, cosine similarity and KL-Divergence. Experiments show that FedDisco with these metrics achieve similar performance, indicating its robustness to different discrepancy metrics.

8 Conclusions

This paper focuses on data heterogeneity issue in FL. Through empirical and theoretical explorations, we find that conventional dataset-size-based aggregation manner could be far from optimal. Addressing these, we introduce a discrepancy value as a complementary indicator and propose FedDisco, a novel FL algorithm that assigns larger aggregation weight to client with larger dataset size and smaller discrepancy. FedDisco introduces negligible computation and communication cost, and can be easily incorporated with many methods. Experiments show that FedDisco consistently achieves state-of-the-art performances.

Though this work mainly explores category-level heterogeneity, we may extend the idea of discrepancy-aware collaboration to other types of heterogeneity, such as feature-level heterogeneity for classification task and mask-level heterogeneity for segmentation task.

Appendix A Methodology

A.1 Complementary Description

Notation table. For convenience, we provide a detailed notation descriptions inÂ TableÂ 8.

Algorithm table. We provide the overall algorithm inÂ AlgorithmÂ 1.

A.2 Discussions

Connection with multi-task learning method, Nash-MTLÂ (Navon etÂ al., 2022). Nash-MTL focuses on aggregation weights of multiple tasks and we focus on aggregation weights of multiple clients. We will cite this paper in the revision. However, there are two major differences between Nash-MTL and our work. 1) Nash-MTL focuses on multi-task learning in a centralized manner while we focus on federated learning in a distributed manner. 2) The aggregation weights in Nash-MTL is learned through minimizing a pre-defined problem to search for Nash bargaining solution, which focuses on pair-wise gradient relationships among multiple tasks. In comparison, our aggregation weights is directly computed based on dataset size and discrepancy level, whose design is guided by our empirical and theoretical observation.

A.3 Obtaining Global Category Distribution in A Privacy-Preserving Manner

InÂ SectionÂ 5, we regard the target distribution ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T} as uniform since we want to emphasize category-level fairness. However, our method is also applicable in scenarios where the global category distribution and test distribution are both non-uniform; see results inÂ TableÂ 5. Here, we show that we can obtain the global category distribution in a privacy-preserving way.

Specifically, we can send each clientâ€™s category distribution ğƒksubscriptğƒğ‘˜\mathbf{D}_{k} (a vector) to the server using Secure AggregationÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) technique such that the server knows the actual global category distribution without knowing each clientâ€™s actual category distribution. Then, this actual category distribution can be sent to each client and the discrepancy can be calculated (this process is efficient as it only requires once). As a simple example for the secure aggregation process, the distribution vectors of Client 1, 2 are ğƒ1subscriptğƒ1\mathbf{D}_{1} and ğƒ2subscriptğƒ2\mathbf{D}_{2}. Client 1 adds an arbitrary noise vector ğšğš\mathbf{a} to ğƒ1subscriptğƒ1\mathbf{D}_{1} to obtain ğƒ1+ğšsubscriptğƒ1ğš\mathbf{D}_{1}+\mathbf{a}; while Client 2 substitutes ğšğš\mathbf{a} from ğƒ2subscriptğƒ2\mathbf{D}_{2} to obtain ğƒ2âˆ’ğšsubscriptğƒ2ğš\mathbf{D}_{2}-\mathbf{a}. These two transformed vectors are then sent to the server, where the server knows the sum of global category distribution without knowing the exact distribution of each client: ğƒ1+ğš+ğƒ2âˆ’ğš=ğƒ1+ğƒ2subscriptğƒ1ğšsubscriptğƒ2ğšsubscriptğƒ1subscriptğƒ2\mathbf{D}_{1}+\mathbf{a}+\mathbf{D}_{2}-\mathbf{a}=\mathbf{D}_{1}+\mathbf{D}_{2}.

Appendix B Experiments

B.1 Implementation details

B.1.1 Environments

We run all methods by using Pytorch frameworkÂ (Paszke etÂ al., 2019) on a single NVIDIA GTX 3090 GPU. The memory occupation ranges from 2065MB to 4413MB for diverse datasets and methods.

B.1.2 Datasets

We use five image classification datasets, which cover medical, natural and artificial images. For medical image classification dataset, we consider HAM10000Â (Codella etÂ al., 2019; Tschandl etÂ al., 2018), a 777 category classification task for pigmented skin lesions. For natual image classification dataset, we consider CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100 and CINIC-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009; Darlow etÂ al., 2018), all of which are classification tasks for natural objects with 101010, 100100100 and 101010 categories, respectively. For artificial image classification dataset, we consider Fashion-MNISTÂ (Xiao etÂ al., 2017), a 101010 category classification task for clothing. All these four public datasets can be downloaded online. Note that for HAM10000, we hold out a uniform testing set by allocating 303030 samples for each category. We use one text classification dataset, AG NewsÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2015), which is a 444 classification task.

B.1.3 Heterogeneity Level

Here, we illustrate the data distribution over categories and clients under NIID-1 setting of four datasets. As mentioned in the main paper, NIID-1 denotes the setting of Dirichlet distribution Dâ€‹iâ€‹rÎ²ğ·ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ›½Dir_{\beta}. We set Î²=0.5ğ›½0.5\beta=0.5 for all datasets except HAM10000 and CIFAR-100. For HAM10000, all methods fail at NIID-1 scenario when Î²ğ›½\beta is too small since HAM10000 is an severely imbalanced dataset. Thus, we choose a moderated Î²=5.0ğ›½5.0\beta=5.0. We also choose Î²=5.0ğ›½5.0\beta=5.0 for CIFAR-100. We plot the NIID-1 data distribution over categories and clients on four datasets in Figure (6). Note that HAM10000 is globally imbalanced and it has the largest number of samples in class 00. For AG News, we partition the dataset to 555 and 505050 clients for full and partial participation scenarios, where 80%percent8080\% biased clients have data samples from 222 categories and the other 20%percent2020\% uniform clients have data samples from 444 categories.

B.1.4 Models

For the CIFAR-10, CINIC-10 and Fashion-MNIST datasets, we use a simple CNN network asÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021; Luo etÂ al., 2021). The network is sequentially consists of: 5Ã—5555\times 5 convolution layer, max-pooling layer, 5Ã—5555\times 5 convolution layer, three fully-connected layer with hidden size of 120120120, 848484 and 101010 respectively. For the HAM10000 and CIFAR-100 dataset, we use ResNet18Â (He etÂ al., 2016) in Pytorch library. We replace the first 7Ã—7777\times 7 convolution layer with a 3Ã—3333\times 3 convolution layer and eliminate the first pooling layer. We also replace the batch normalization layer with group normalization layer asÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2020). For AG NewsÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2015), we use TextCNN modelÂ (Zhang & Wallace, 2015) with a 323232 hidden dimension.

B.1.5 Hyper-parameters

For all methods, we tune the hyper-parameter in a reasonable range and report the highest accuracy in the paper. For FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a), we tune the hyper-parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu from {0.001,0.01,0.1,1.0}0.0010.010.11.0\{0.001,0.01,0.1,1.0\}. For FedAvgMÂ (Hsu etÂ al., 2019), we tune the hyper-parameter Î²ğ›½\beta from {0.3,0.5,0.7,0.9}0.30.50.70.9\{0.3,0.5,0.7,0.9\}. For FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2020), we tune the hyper-parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha from {0.001,0.01,0.1,1.0}0.0010.010.11.0\{0.001,0.01,0.1,1.0\}. For MOONÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021), we tune the hyper-parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu from {0.01,0.1,0.5,1.0,5.0}0.010.10.51.05.0\{0.01,0.1,0.5,1.0,5.0\}. For FedDCÂ (Gao etÂ al., 2022), we tune the hyper-parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha from {0.001,0.01,0.1,1.0}0.0010.010.11.0\{0.001,0.01,0.1,1.0\}.

The tuned best hyper-parameter for these methods are: Î¼=0.01ğœ‡0.01\mu=0.01 in FedProxÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a), Î²=0.5ğ›½0.5\beta=0.5 in FedAvgMÂ (Hsu etÂ al., 2019), Î±=0.01ğ›¼0.01\alpha=0.01 in FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2020), Î¼=0.1ğœ‡0.1\mu=0.1 in MOONÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021), Î±=0.01ğ›¼0.01\alpha=0.01 in FedDCÂ (Gao etÂ al., 2022).

B.2 Globally Imbalanced Scenario: Accuracy and Fairness

We show that our proposed FedDisco is also capable of globally imbalanced category distribution scenario, that is the hypothetically aggregated global data is imbalanced. In the main paper, we show the performance of FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) and FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2020) with and without Disco for different globally imbalance level (Ï=1,2,5,10,20ğœŒ1251020\rho={1,2,5,10,20}) in Figure 5 (a).

We firstly visualize the hypothetically aggregated global data distribution in FigureÂ 7, where x-axis denotes the category and y-axis denotes the number of data samples of the corresponding category. We plot the data distribution over categories for different globally imbalance levels (ÏğœŒ\rho). Ï=1ğœŒ1\rho=1 denotes balanced situation and Ï=20ğœŒ20\rho=20 denotes the most severe imbalanced situation. Our experiments in the Figure 5 (a) of the main paper show that our FedDisco works for all these globally imbalance levels.

Next, we provide the performance of more baselines when Ï=10ğœŒ10\rho=10 in Table 9. Experiments show that our proposed FedDisco consistently improves over baselines under this globally imbalanced scenario, indicating its applicability to this scenario.

We also explore the performance of global model on each individual category in detail in FigureÂ 8. Here, we use FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) as an example. FollowingÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2021), we define and evaluate on three subsets: Head (category 1 - 4), Middle (category 5 - 7) and Tail (category 8 - 10). Additionally, we report the averaged accuracy over all categories and standard deviation across categories. We see that i) FedDisco achieves comparable performance (difference within 0.75%percent0.750.75\%) on Head and Middle classes and significantly higher performance (nearly 8%percent88\% improvement) on Tail classes. This suggests that FedAvg is severally biased to Head classes while FedDisco can mitigate this bias. ii) FedDisco achieves higher averaged accuracy with smaller standard deviation, which means FedDisco can simultaneous enhance overall performance and promote fairness across categories.

B.3 Partial Client Participation Scenario: Accuracy, Stability and Training Speed

In practice, clients may participate only when they are in reliable power and Wi-Fi condition, indicating that only a subset of clients participate in each round (partial client participation). We conduct experiments on CIFAR-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) where there are 404040 biased clients and 101010 unbiased clients. In each round, we randomly sample 101010 clients to participate.

We show results from two aspects in Table 10, including the mean and standard deviation (std) of accuracy of last 101010 rounds and rounds required to reach target accuracy (55%percent5555\%). Experiments show that methods with our Disco achieve i) consistently higher mean and smaller std of accuracy, indicating better and more stable performance over rounds, ii) fewer rounds to achieve target accuracy, indicating faster training speed, which is friendly to save computation and communication cost. Specifically, for the basic method FedAvg, FedAvg with Disco achieves 7.32%percent7.327.32\% accuracy improvement and requires 383838 less rounds to achieve the target accuracy, which saves 65.52%percent65.5265.52\% training time and communication cost.

B.4 Experimental results on CIFAR-100

We provide the results of several baselines on CIFAR-100Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) under NIID-1 setting in Table 11. Experiments show that our proposed FedDisco consistently brings gains on CIFAR-100 dataset, verifying its modularity performance.

B.5 Effects on Client-Level Fairness

In this paper, we focus on the generalization ability and promote category-level fairness, where the corresponding global distribution is uniform. Client-level fairness is another interesting and important research topic in FLÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b). Here, we explore from this aspect for more comprehensive understanding.

Note that FedDisco does not hurt client-level fairness for two reasons. First, when a clientâ€™s aggregation weight is high, this client has a uniform training distribution, which can naturally benefit all the clients more or less. If we do the opposite thing and assign a high aggregation weight to a client whose training category distribution is highly skewed, this only benefits this single client, hurts the other clients and violates the client-level fairness. Second, each clientâ€™s test data distribution could be close to uniform distribution, even though its training data distribution is far from uniform. One important aim of federated learning is to enable clients with biased and limited training data to be aware of global distribution.

To validate that FedDisco does not hurt client-level fairness, we run 404040 rounds of FL on CIFAR-10 and record the variance of test accuracy across clients. This accuracy variance is often used for evaluation of fairnessÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020b). Small variance denotes that the test accuracies of clients are similar, indicating high fairness. Thus, a lower variance denotes higher fairness. TableÂ 12 compares the accuracy variance of FedAvg and the accuracy variance after applying FedDisco to FedAvg. From the table, we see that the variance of FedDisco is comparable or lower than FedAvg, indicating that FedDisco can potentially enhance the client-level fairness.

B.6 Comparison with Equal Aggregation Weights

Following the experiments inÂ TableÂ 1, TableÂ 13 compares FedDisco with FedAvg with equal aggregation weights (i.e., pk=1/Ksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1ğ¾p_{k}=1/K). From the table, we see that FedDisco performs significantly better across different settings.

B.7 Experiments on Device Heterogeneity

For device heterogeneity where there are stragglers, we conduct experiments with the NIID-2 setting on CIFAR-10 following the setting inÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020b), where we uniformly sample iteration numbers for each client in the range of 505050 to 500500500 for each round. Results show that FedAvg achieves 60.21%percent60.2160.21\% while FedDisco achieves 63.20%percent63.2063.20\%, indicating that FedDisco can still bring performance improvement under setting of stragglers.

Device heterogeneity is an orthogonal issue to distribution heterogeneity. As these two issues can be concurrent in practice, FedDisco can still play a role in enhancing overall performance. More importantly, device heterogeneity can even exacerbate the effect of distribution heterogeneity. For example, if Client A has a smaller discrepancy level and Client B has a larger discrepancy level. When Client A is a straggler that performs fewer iterations while Client B performs much more iterations, it is more critical to enhance the aggregation weight of Client A, otherwise the FL system will be dominated by Client B and the global model will be biased. Further, we can combine algorithms (e.g., FedNovaÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020b)) that specifically focuses on device heterogeneity with ours to further enhance performance.

B.8 Other Experiments

1) The idea of discrepancy-aware collaboration can be extended to otehr tasks such as regression. Here, we conduct experiments on regression dataset Prediction of Facebook CommentÂ (Singh etÂ al., 2015) (predicting the number of comments given a post). We pre-define several categories for this regression task, where each category covers regression labels in some specific range. For example, we group those samples with regression labels ranging from 1 to 10 as category 1. With this strategy, we can obtain a distribution vector as we do for classification tasks. Note that such operation is only conducted for obtaining a distribution vector, we still use the regression labels for model training. It turns out that the test loss of FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) is 0.432 and FedDisco achieves 0.407, indicating our FedDisco can also handle continuous label distributions.

2) Here, we consider feature-level heterogeneity. We conduct experiments on FEMNIST from LEAF benchmarkÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018) followingÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a), where both feature-level and category-level heterogeneity exist. We see that FedAvg achieves 76.40%percent76.4076.40\% accuracy while FedDisco achieves 78.36%percent78.3678.36\% accuracy.

C.4 Further Analysis with Proper Learning Rate

As a conventional setting in theoretical literature, we can set the learning rate Î·=1Ï„â€‹Tğœ‚1ğœğ‘‡\eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\tau T}}Â (Wang etÂ al., 2020b). Here, note that the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta is strongly correlated with the number of communication round Tğ‘‡T. Then, there are two typical cases:

Tğ‘‡T is finite and relatively small. According to Î·=1Ï„â€‹Tğœ‚1ğœğ‘‡\eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\tau T}}, the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta will be relatively large. Then, A=2â€‹Ï„â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)â€‹Î·2â€‹L2ğ´2ğœğœ1superscriptğœ‚2superscriptğ¿2A=2\tau(\tau-1)\eta^{2}L^{2} will be relatively large and (1âˆ’A)1ğ´(1-A) will be relatively small. As a result, T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2} will be relatively small and T5subscriptğ‘‡5T_{5} will be relatively large, making T5subscriptğ‘‡5T_{5} a dominant term in the optimization bound. Thus, in this case, tuning pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} to make T5subscriptğ‘‡5T_{5} smaller is a better solution such that the ağ‘a and bğ‘b inÂ EquationÂ 2 will be non-zero and the overall upper bound could be tighter.

Tğ‘‡T is quite large or infinite. the learning rate Î·=1Ï„â€‹Tğœ‚1ğœğ‘‡\eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\tau T}} will be relatively small. Then, A=2â€‹Ï„â€‹(Ï„âˆ’1)â€‹Î·2â€‹L2ğ´2ğœğœ1superscriptğœ‚2superscriptğ¿2A=2\tau(\tau-1)\eta^{2}L^{2} will be relatively small and (1âˆ’A)1ğ´(1-A) will be relatively large. As a result, T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2} will be relatively large and T5subscriptğ‘‡5T_{5} will be relatively small, making T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2} a dominant term in the optimization bound. Thus, in this case, tuning pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} to make T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2} smaller is a better solution. To achieve this, WDsubscriptğ‘Šğ·W_{D} should be reduced to zero and thus ağ‘a and bğ‘b inÂ EquationÂ 2 will zero to make the upper bound tight. Here, we can have the following corollary:

Corollary C.2.

By substituting Î·=1Ï„â€‹Tğœ‚1ğœğ‘‡\eta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\tau T}} intoÂ TheoremÂ 4.5, we will have the following bound:

mintğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°(t,0))â€–2â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹(1Ï„â€‹T)+ğ’ªâ€‹(1T)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„T).subscriptğ‘¡ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹superscriptğ°ğ‘¡02ğ’ª1ğœğ‘‡ğ’ª1ğ‘‡ğ’ªğœğ‘‡\mathop{\min}_{t}\mathbb{E}||\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{(t,0)})||^{2}\leq\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{\tau T}})+\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{T})+\mathcal{O}(\frac{\tau}{T}). (53)

CorollaryÂ C.2 indicates that as Tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘‡T\rightarrow\infty, the optimization upper bound approaches 00 (reaches a stationary point) and matches with previous convergence resultsÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020b).

As the ultimate goal of this paper is to achieve more pleasant performance in practice, we are more interested in the previous part that the number of communication round Tğ‘‡T is finite (Tğ‘‡T should not be too large due to issues such as communication burden). For this reason, we explore better aggregation weights to achieve a tighter upper bound in this paper. However, our algorithm can actually converge (reach a stationary point) based on ourÂ TheoremÂ 4.5 and CorollaryÂ C.2 if the number of communication round goes to infinite.

C.5 Reformulated Upper Bound Minimization

Generally, a tighter bound corresponds to a better optimization result. Thus, we explore the effects of pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} on the upper bound in (49). InÂ TheoremÂ 4.5, there there are four parts related to pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}. First, we see that larger difference between pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} and nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} contributes to larger WDsubscriptğ‘Šğ·W_{D} and thus smaller denominator in T0subscriptğ‘‡0T_{0} and larger value in T2subscriptğ‘‡2T_{2}, which tends to loose the bound. As for T5subscriptğ‘‡5T_{5}, by setting pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} negatively correlated to dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k}, when clients have different level of discrepancy, i.e. different dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k}, T5subscriptğ‘‡5T_{5} will be further reduced, which tends to tighten the bound. Therefore, there could be an optimal set of {pk|kâˆˆ[K]}conditional-setsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\{p_{k}|k\in[K]\} that contributes to the tightest bound, where an optimal pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} should be correlated to both nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} and dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k}.

To minimize this upper bound, directly solving the minimization results in a complicated expression, which involves too many unknown hyper-parameters in practice. To simplify the expression, we convert the original objective from minimizing (T1+T2+T3+T4+T5)/T0subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘‡2subscriptğ‘‡3subscriptğ‘‡4subscriptğ‘‡5subscriptğ‘‡0(T_{1}+T_{2}+T_{3}+T_{4}+T_{5})/T_{0} to minimizing T1+T2+T3+T4+T5âˆ’Î»â€‹T0subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘‡2subscriptğ‘‡3subscriptğ‘‡4subscriptğ‘‡5ğœ†subscriptğ‘‡0T_{1}+T_{2}+T_{3}+T_{4}+T_{5}-\lambda T_{0}, where Î»ğœ†\lambda is a hyper-parameter. The converted objective still promotes maximization of T0subscriptğ‘‡0T_{0} and minimization of T1+T2+T3+T4+T5subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘‡2subscriptğ‘‡3subscriptğ‘‡4subscriptğ‘‡5T_{1}+T_{2}+T_{3}+T_{4}+T_{5}, and still contributes to tighten the bound (T1+T2+T3+T4+T5)/T0subscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘‡2subscriptğ‘‡3subscriptğ‘‡4subscriptğ‘‡5subscriptğ‘‡0(T_{1}+T_{2}+T_{3}+T_{4}+T_{5})/T_{0}. Then, our discrepancy-aware aggregation weight is obtained through solving the following optimization problem:

from which we can rearrange and obtain the expression of pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}:

pk=[4â€‹Bâ€‹(1âˆ’A)â€‹âˆ‘m=1Kdm+4â€‹Kâ€‹Î»â€‹(1âˆ’A)]â€‹nkâˆ’2â€‹Aâ€‹Bâ€‹dkâˆ’Î¼+Î½k4â€‹Bâ€‹(1âˆ’A)â€‹âˆ‘m=1Kdm+4â€‹(1âˆ’A)â€‹Lâ€‹Î·â€‹Ïƒ2+4â€‹Kâ€‹Î»â€‹(1âˆ’A).subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜delimited-[]4ğµ1ğ´superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ¾subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘š4ğ¾ğœ†1ğ´subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜2ğ´ğµsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜ğœ‡subscriptğœˆğ‘˜4ğµ1ğ´superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ¾subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘š41ğ´ğ¿ğœ‚superscriptğœ24ğ¾ğœ†1ğ´p_{k}=\frac{\left[4B(1-A)\sum_{m=1}^{K}d_{m}+4K\lambda(1-A)\right]n_{k}-2ABd_{k}-\mu+\nu_{k}}{4B(1-A)\sum_{m=1}^{K}d_{m}+4(1-A)L\eta\sigma^{2}+4K\lambda(1-A)}. Finally, we can derive the following concise expression of an optimized aggregation weight pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}:

pkâˆnkâˆ’aâ‹…dk+b,proportional-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜â‹…ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜ğ‘p_{k}\propto n_{k}-a\cdot d_{k}+b, (55)

where a,bğ‘ğ‘a,b are two constants.

This theoretically show that simply dataset-size-based aggregation could be not optimal since the above analysis suggests that for a tighter upper bound, the aggregation weight pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k} should be correlated with both dataset size nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} and local discrepancy level dksubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜d_{k}. This expression of aggregation weight can mitigate the limitation of standard dataset size weighted aggregation by assigning larger aggregation weight to client with larger dataset size and smaller discrepancy level.
